meaning: adj., sense 1: “Originally Scottish. Of a person: not liable or subject to a criminal charge. Also (of an action or condition): not related to a criminal charge…”
n., sense 2: “In plural. slang. The eyes (cf. light, n.¹ II.6b). Now only in historical contexts.”
n.¹, sense 2: “Originally U.S. With reference to a commercial vehicle: the practice of travelling without freight or passengers. Cf. deadhead, v. 2.”
n., sense 2: “Chiefly Australian. A horse that naturally runs or races hard and fast. Now rare.”
noun, a period during which people feel very worried and pessimistic about the economy when in fact it is in a strong position
n., sense 2: “Music. An advocate of the performance of plainsong in notes of equal duration. Contrasted with mensuralist, n.”
n.¹: “A restaurant, food counter, kitchen, etc., serving (esp. Cantonese) dishes cooked using a wok. Also: the skill or activity of cooking using a wok.”
n., sense 1.a: “The action or an act of turning round; esp. an act of turning to face or move in the opposite direction. Cf. turnaround, n. A.1a.”
adj., sense 1: “That prevents ugliness. rare before 20th cent.”
v., sense 1: “intransitive. To intoxicate; to make a person drunk. Obsolete.”
n., sense 1: “That which drags someone or something back; a hindrance or impediment.”
n.: “With the and plural agreement. Incapable, lazy, or indolent people collectively.”
adj., sense 2: “Causing a person to become red-faced and dishevelled. Obsolete.”
n., sense 1: “A conviction that one is suited or destined for a particular employment. Obsolete. rare.”
n., sense 1: “Expulsion of an evil spirit from a person.”
noun, a type of Botox injected into the trapezius muscle
n.¹: “Chiefly British. A heraldic representation of a wicker basket trap used to catch fish; (sometimes also) a trap of this type.”
n.: “One's own legs as a means of conveyance, esp. over long distances; walking, as distinguished from driving, riding, etc.”
n., sense 2.b: “figurative and in figurative contexts. slang. Sexual activity; sexual intercourse. Obsolete.”
noun, a way of describing a large language model, because it can produce text that sounds natural but it does not understand what it is saying
n., sense 1: “A person who is not an advocate of open warfare or armed conflict. Obsolete. rare.”
n.: “In knitting and crochet: a partial row in which only a portion of the stitches are worked before the work is turned, typically used to create shaping.”
n.: “A soft, round cap in the style of a type popular in the 16th and early 17th centuries, having a low crown and a narrow brim, frequently with a tassel…”
noun, anger or violence between a driver who is charging their electric vehicle and other drivers who are waiting in a queue to do so
noun, a holiday lasting a few days, taken during a period when there are no public holidays
noun, someone’s inability to remember how their natural face looks after they have had a number of cosmetic procedures such as Botox
n., sense 2: “In figurative and similative use, denoting someone or something displaying frenetic energy or activity regarded as resembling the ritual practice of…”
noun, the activity of saving less money for the future and spending more now to enjoy a better quality of life
n.¹, sense I.5: “A type of metal sieve or strainer with a conical shape.”
adj., sense 1: “Completely or uniformly level; (in extended use) unvaried, monotonous.”
v.: “transitive. To persuade (a person) to comply with or do something. Cf. to talk round at phrasal verbs PV.1.”
noun, the activity of going for long walks in the countryside without any pressure to walk fast, climb hills or cover a certain distance
noun, someone who thinks their country has many serious problems caused by politicians and other people in a position of power, and that these people should not be trusted at all
n., sense 6: “A blog post featuring a selection of links to blog articles on other websites, typically covering a specific topic or theme, that have been nominated…”
adj., sense 1.b: “Of things: shared. Obsolete.”

v., sense IV.15.b.i: “transitive. Sport (chiefly Rugby and Football (Soccer)). With down. To block (a kick, hit, ball, etc.) by rushing towards the kicker and intercepting…”

adj., sense 14.b: “Music. Of a beat: unaccented; (of the accent on a beat) having relatively little force, light.”
v., sense VIII.81: “intransitive. Originally U.S. To perform an energetic dance to hip-hop music; to breakdance. Cf. earlier breaking, n. 11.”
v.¹, sense II.16: “intransitive. Sport. Of a ball: to stop moving, to lose momentum; spec. (Golf) to stop moving so near the hole that the ball can be holed with…”
v., sense V.35.a: “transitive. To bring (a body of water) to rest; to calm.”

n.¹, sense 5.b: “A tapering section or component at the base of a hollow needle by means of which it may be attached to a syringe, catheter, or the like.”
n., sense III.22: “U.S. slang. A suit of clothes; an outfit. Now rare.”
v., sense III.7.b: “transitive. To initiate or bring about (contact or communication). Frequently with between, with, etc.”
